text:
Hi, my name is Chris Hennesey,
and I'm an Enterprise
Strategist at AWS.

I am on a team of ex-CxOs
who led large-scale transformations

at their prior employers
and now inspire and support
AWS customers on their transformation.

Before joining AWS, I was an IT
CFO at Capital One, where I worked
for over 20 years.

I now engage with CFOs and CIOs
across the globe, guiding

them on best practices
and lessons learned to accelerate

their modernization
journey.
So what is the cloud?

The cloud refers to the on-demand
delivery of IT resources

over the internet with pay-as-you-go
pricing.

Instead of buying, and owning,
and maintaining physical

data centers and servers,
you can access technology

services, such as compute,
storage, and databases,

on an as-needed basis from a cloud
provider.

CFOs care a lot about the cloud
because it can provide material
benefits to their organizations.

Benefits may include significant
cost savings and increased

operational efficiency,
plus scalability and flexibility

to quickly adjust to changing
IT demands.

By using the cloud, your organization
can reduce the costs associated

with building and maintaining
in-house IT infrastructure.

For cloud resources, you only
pay for when they are being
used.

Resources are elastic and can scale
up and down according to demand.

This can result in reduced
labor costs to run and monitor

your data centers and lower
energy and water consumption.

It can also reduce upfront
costs while eliminating

the waste of underused
infrastructure.

Additionally, the cloud provides
access to the latest technologies

that can help drive innovation
within your organization
to differentiate itself.

It can also empower advanced
capabilities, such as data analytics,

that take advantage of artificial
intelligence and machine

learning, so CFOs and other
leaders can make better decisions.

Moreover, the cloud helps your
organization increase business
agility.

Removing time-consuming
and complex IT procurement

and deployment processes
can help your organization

implement new services and applications
quickly.

At the same time, you can increase
resources rapidly to meet spikes
in customer interest and demand.

This can lead to increased
revenue, faster time-to-market,
and improved customer experiences.

In summary, the cloud offers
CFOs a way to save costs,

increase efficiency,
and improve business outcomes.
